In addition to memorableness, still photography has clear advantages over video. For one, a photo can be comprehended in one glimpse. Not so with video, which has to be watched for several frames for the relevant action and sometimes only after waiting through a commercial, some as long as 30 seconds, an eternity online.

Even longer photo essays give more control to the viewer who can click next, next, next, or stop and muse over a particular image. No so with videos. Sure one can pause a video, but what's to see? A grainy pixilated image with motion blur? The value of the video is that it shows continuous motion, and that with the right heading, is more likely to go viral on social media than a still.

But time and shortening attention spans are on the side of the still photograph.

Professor Krugman, I think you have identified the key problem, that low-inflation stagnant growth may be "the new normal." It appears that elites have found the right balance of forces to maintain high profits while keeping popular discontent contained, so it's unclear where any impetus for changing this equilibrium could come from.

But it seems to me that you overlook the fact that it is an equilibrium of political and economic forces. Perhaps this is where the next investigation should be focused: how can current equilibrium be changed? Some would argue that minimizing the impact of large-dollar political contributions could have impact; another exogenous shock, like another energy crisis, could change the political calculus. The continuing rise of inequality could also be a catalyst for popular protest.

There is still a great deal of popular discontent out there, but the people who might form a popular opposition are disorganized, and lack a clear sense of how to proceed. I'd offer two questions in this regard. First, is there a policy outcome that could restore the relationship of profitability to the level of employment? Second, what is the single demand, which could get popular support, that could change the current equilibrium?

Mr Velazquez quotes the Declaration:
"He[referring to King George],has endeavored to prevent the population of these States; for that purpose obstructing the Laws for Naturalization of Foreigners; refusing to pass others to encourage their migration hither; and raising the conditions of new Appropriations of Lands."

This is not 1776, The founders wrote for a huge, largely unexplored continent and a sparse, largely agrarian population. They and their colleagues and descendants did indeed populate these states, largely by expelling and exterminating the tribes who were already populating it. The frontier officially closed a century ago.

Being an originalist and strict constructionist with regard to the Declaration is as absurd as being a strict constructionist and originalist with regard to the Constitution. It's like a middle-aged man trying to fit into his middle-school jeans - or his onesie.

The nation of which Jefferson wrote was almost entirely unexplored, and was a sparsely populated, largely agrarian society. The land which they sought to appropriate, they appropriated by exterminating the tribes who were here first.

Trying to fit the entire Declaration to current reality is like a middle-aged man trying to squeeze into his junior high school jeans -- or his onesie.

Every 4rth I bring out the Decoration of Independence and read the eloquent ideals written by Thomas Jefferson with some help from John Adams. Somewhere in the middle of this great document, a paragraph reads as follows: "He[referring to King George],has endeavored to prevent the population of these States; for that purpose obstructing the Laws for Naturalization of Foreigners; refusing to pass others to encourage their migration hither; and raising the conditions of new Appropriations of Lands."
Clearly even than, our Founding Fathers understood that to establish a new nation, equal to the Great Powers, the proses required immigration. Why does the GOP and its followers refuse to see the wisdom of the Founders so clearly stated in the great document? Perhaps they have not it.
Please explain?

The Senate bill was a compromise. It wasn't perfect, but it passed the Senate with 68 votes including 14 Republicans. This is a miracle!! It includes the most generous Dream Act ever -- the Dreamers and farmworkers get a 5 year path to citizenship. Did you hear that? And the bill leaves a pathway to citizenship intact for all 11 million. Not all will make it through the arduous and hard path -- and yes, there is that work requirement that does not allow more than 2 months of unemployment. However, immigrants are hard working people - Latino immigrant men have the highest labor force participation rate of any demographic group in the U.S. And spouses who are stay-at-home moms get to be included on the application of their husbands. There are also exemptions to the work requirement due to health issues. The majority of them will make it.

This bill does remind me of what our democracy is still capable of. They passed a hard bill and it's far from perfect. e.g. they weakened labor protections through amendments, yet there were many even more horrible amendments that were introduced but did not pass. Our still-functional Senate was able to strategically agree on the amendments that did not fundamentally damage the heart of the bill. I give them a standing ovation for producing a bill that solves many big problems and still passed with strong bipartisan support.
